message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of symptoms and the improvement after 10 minutes suggest a transient ischemic attack (TIA). Among the options, vertebral artery occlusion is the most likely cause based on the patient's symptoms (dizziness and ataxia) and risk factors (smoking history). Middle cerebral artery occlusion and posterior cerebral artery occlusion would present with more severe and longer-lasting symptoms. Lenticulostriate artery occlusion would present with focal neurological deficits.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The rapid onset of severe dizziness and difficulty swallowing with subtle nystagmus and ataxia suggest a vertebrobasilar insufficiency. Among the options, only vertebral artery occlusion affects the posterior circulation and can cause vertebrobasilar insufficiency. Middle cerebral artery occlusion affects the middle cerebral artery territory and will cause contralateral motor and sensory deficits. Posterior cerebral artery occlusion will cause contralateral upper and lower visual field defects. Lenticulostriate artery occlusion will cause contralateral motor and sensory deficits.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The abrupt onset of symptoms, with improvement within 10 minutes, suggests a transient ischemic attack (TIA). The combination of dizziness, difficulty swallowing, and ataxia suggest that the most likely cause is a vertebral artery occlusion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of symptoms and improvement within minutes suggest a transient ischemic attack (TIA). Among the options, vertebral artery occlusion is most likely to cause the symptoms described, including dizziness, difficulty swallowing, ataxia, and nystagmus. Middle cerebral artery occlusion may cause hemiparesis, sensory loss, and aphasia. Posterior cerebral artery occlusion may cause visual field defects and sensory loss. Lenticulostriate artery occlusion may cause hemiparesis and dysarthria.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient had sudden onset of symptoms including dizziness, difficulty swallowing, and ataxia, which suggests vertebrobasilar insufficiency. The fact that symptoms improved after 10 minutes also supports this diagnosis. Among the options, vertebral artery occlusion is the most common cause of vertebrobasilar insufficiency.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The rapid onset of severe dizziness and difficulty swallowing with improvement after 10 minutes, as well as a subtle nystagmus and ataxia suggest vertebrobasilar insufficiency. Among the options, only vertebral artery occlusion is related to this condition. The other options are related to different types of stroke.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset, dizziness, difficulty swallowing, ataxia, and nystagmus all suggest a vertebrobasilar insufficiency, which could be caused by vertebral artery occlusion. Middle cerebral artery occlusion would cause hemiplegia or hemiparesis, which the patient did not have. Posterior cerebral artery occlusion would cause visual field deficits or cognitive deficits, which the patient did not have. Lenticulostriate artery occlusion would cause motor or sensory deficits in specific regions, which the patient did not have.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient had a rapid onset of dizziness and difficulty swallowing, which suggests a posterior circulation stroke. The quick resolution of symptoms also suggests a transient ischemic attack (TIA). Among the options, vertebral artery occlusion is the most likely cause of a TIA in the posterior circulation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of symptoms suggests an acute ischemic stroke. Since symptoms resolved within 10 minutes, this is likely a transient ischemic attack (TIA). The patient’s subtle nystagmus and ataxia suggest a vestibular TIA, which is most commonly caused by vertebral artery occlusion. Middle cerebral artery occlusion would cause hemiparesis and language deficits. Posterior cerebral artery occlusion would cause visual deficits. Lenticulostriate artery occlusion would cause motor and sensory deficits.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The rapid onset of symptoms suggests a transient ischemic attack (TIA) or mini-stroke. The symptoms of dizziness, difficulty swallowing, ataxia, and subtle nystagmus are all signs of a vertebral artery occlusion. Middle cerebral artery occlusion would present with contralateral hemiparesis and posterior cerebral artery occlusion would present with contralateral homonymous hemianopsia. Lenticulostriate artery occlusion would present with contralateral hemiparesis and unilateral sensory loss.
